data.name: Forensics Warmup 1
data.description: Can you unzip this file for me and retreive the flag?
hints: Make sure to submit the flag as picoCTF{XXXXX}
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: Forensics Warmup 2
data.description: Hmm for some reason I can't open this PNG? Any ideas?
hints: How do operating systems know what kind of file it is? (It's not just the ending!
Make sure to submit the flag as picoCTF{XXXXX}
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: General Warmup 1
data.description: If I told you your grade was 0x41 in hexadecimal, what would it be in ASCII?
hints: Submit your answer in our competition's flag format. For example, if you answer was 'hello', you would submit 'picoCTF{hello}' as the flag.
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: General Warmup 2
data.description: Can you convert the number 27 (base 10) to binary (base 2)?
hints: Submit your answer in our competition's flag format. For example, if you answer was '11111', you would submit 'picoCTF{11111}' as the flag.
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: General Warmup 3
data.description: What is 0x3D (base 16) in decimal (base 10).
hints: Submit your answer in our competition's flag format. For example, if you answer was '22', you would submit 'picoCTF{22}' as the flag.
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: Resources
data.description: We put together a bunch of resources to help you out on our website! If you go over there, you might even find a flag! https://picoctf.com/resources (link)
data.author: Alex Fulton

data.name: Reversing Warmup 1
data.description: Throughout your journey you will have to run many programs. Can you navigate to /problems/reversing-warmup-1_1_b416a2d0694c871d8728d8268d84ac5c on the shell server and run this program to retreive the flag?
hints: If you are searching online, it might be worth finding how to exeucte a program in command line.
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: Reversing Warmup 2
data.description: Can you decode the following string dGg0dF93NHNfczFtcEwz from base64 format to ASCII?
hints: Submit your answer in our competition's flag format. For example, if you answer was 'hello', you would submit 'picoCTF{hello}' as the flag.
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: Crypto Warmup 1
data.description: Crpyto can often be done by hand, here's a message you got from a friend, llkjmlmpadkkc with the key of thisisalilkey. Can you use this table to solve it?.
hints: Submit your answer in our competition's flag format. For example, if you answer was 'hello', you would submit 'picoCTF{HELLO}' as the flag.
Please use all caps for the message.
data.author: Alex Fulton

data.name: Crypto Warmup 2
data.description: Cryptography doesn't have to be complicated, have you ever heard of something called rot13? cvpbPGS{guvf_vf_pelcgb!}
hints: This can be solved online if you don't want to do it by hand!
data.author: Alex Fulton

data.name: grep 1
data.description: Can you find the flag in file? This would be really obnoxious to look through by hand, see if you can find a faster way. You can also find the file in /problems/grep-1_1_35b9930ca897512a4d00b43d26eac73d on the shell server.
hints: grep tutorial
data.author: Alex Fulton

data.name: net cat
data.description: Using netcat (nc) will be a necessity throughout your adventure. Can you connect to 2018shell2.picoctf.com at port 22847 to get the flag?
hints: nc tutorial
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: HEEEEEEERE'S Johnny!
data.description: Okay, so we found some important looking files on a linux computer. Maybe they can be used to get a password to the process. Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 35225. Files can be found here: passwd shadow.
hints: If at first you don't succeed, try, try again. And again. And again.
If you're not careful these kind of problems can really "rockyou".
data.author: Sam Dlinn

data.name: strings
data.description: Can you find the flag in this file without actually running it? You can also find the file in /problems/strings_3_1dbaafa1f8f0556872cad33e16bc8dc7 on the shell server.
hints: strings
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: pipe
data.description: During your adventure, you will likely encounter a situation where you need to process data that you receive over the network rather than through a file. Can you find a way to save the output from this program and search for the flag? Connect with 2018shell2.picoctf.com 37542.
hints: Remember the flag format is picoCTF{XXXX}
Ever heard of a pipe? No not that kind of pipe... This kind
data.author: Alex Fulton

data.name: Inspect Me
data.description: Inpect this code! http://2018shell2.picoctf.com:47428 (link)
hints: How do you inspect a website's code on a browser?
Check all the website code.
data.author: zaratec

data.name: grep 2
data.description: This one is a little bit harder. Can you find the flag in /problems/grep-2_3_826f886f547acb8a9c3fccb030e8168d/files on the shell server? Remember, grep is your friend.
hints: grep tutorial
data.author: Alex Fulton

data.name: Aca-Shell-A
data.description: It's never a bad idea to brush up on those linux skills or even learn some new ones before you set off on this adventure! Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 42334.
hints: Linux for Beginners
data.author: Everett Montano

data.name: Client Side is Still Bad
data.description: I forgot my password again, but this time there doesn't seem to be a reset, can you help me? http://2018shell2.picoctf.com:8420 (link)
hints: Client Side really is a bad way to do it.
data.author: Alex Fulton

data.name: Desrouleaux
data.description: Our network administrator is having some trouble handling the tickets for all of of our incidents. Can you help him out by answering all the questions? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 10493. incidents.json
hints: If you need to code, python has some good libraries for it.
data.author: Carson Sestili

data.name: Logon
data.description: I made a website so now you can log on to! I don't seem to have the admin password. See if you can't get to the flag. http://2018shell2.picoctf.com:62746 (link)
hints: Hmm it doesn't seem to check anyone's password, except for admins?
How does check the admin's password?
data.author: bobson

data.name: Reading Between the Eyes
data.description: Stego-Saurus hid a message for you in this image, can you retreive it?
hints: Maybe you can find an online decoder?
data.author: Julio de la Cruz Natera

data.name: Recovering From the Snap
data.description: There used to be a bunch of animals here, what did Dr. Xernon do to them?
hints: Some files have been deleted from the disk image, but are they really gone?
data.author: Julio de la Cruz Natera

data.name: admin panel
data.description: We captured some traffic logging into the admin panel, can you find the password?
hints: Tools like wireshark are pretty good for analyzing pcap files.
data.author: Alex Fulton

data.name: assembly-0
data.description: What does asm0(0xd8,0x7a) return? Submit the flag as a hexadecimal value (starting with '0x'). NOTE: Your submission for this question will NOT be in the normal flag format. Source located in the directory at /problems/assembly-0_1_fc43dbf0079fd5aab87236bf3bf4ac63.
hints: basical assembly tutorial
assembly registers
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: buffer overflow 0
data.description: Let's start off simple, can you overflow the right buffer in this program to get the flag? You can also find it in /problems/buffer-overflow-0_0_6461b382721ccca2318b1d981d363924 on the shell server. Source.
hints: How can you trigger the flag to print?
If you try to do the math by hand, maybe try and add a few more characters. Sometimes there are things you aren't expecting.
data.author: Alex Fulton

data.name: caesar cipher 1
data.description: This is one of the older ciphers in the books, can you decrypt the message? You can find the ciphertext in /problems/caesar-cipher-1_3_160978e2a142244574bd048623dba1ed on the shell server.
hints: caesar cipher tutorial
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: environ
data.description: Sometimes you have to configure environment variables before executing a program. Can you find the flag we've hidden in an environment variable on the shell server?
hints: unix env
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: hertz
data.author: invisibility
data.description: Here's another simple cipher for you where we made a bunch of substitutions. Can you decrypt it? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 43324.
hints: NOTE: Flag is not in the usual flag format

data.description: This cat has a secret to teach you. You can also find the file in /problems/hex-editor_4_0a7282b29fa47d68c3e2917a5a0d726b on the shell server.
data.author: jedavis
data.name: hex editor
hints: What is a hex editor?
Maybe google knows.
xxd
hexedit
bvi

data.name: ssh-keyz
data.description: As nice as it is to use our webshell, sometimes its helpful to connect directly to our machine. To do so, please add your own public key to ~/.ssh/authorized_keys, using the webshell. The flag is in the ssh banner which will be displayed when you login remotely with ssh to  with your username.
hints: key generation tutorial
We also have an expert demonstrator to help you along. link
data.author: Alex Fulton

data.name: Irish Name Repo
data.description: There is a website running at http://2018shell2.picoctf.com:59464 (link). Do you think you can log us in? Try to see if you can login!
hints: There doesn't seem to be many ways to interact with this, I wonder if the users are kept in a database?
data.author: Chris Hensler

data.name: Mr. Robots
data.description: Do you see the same things I see? The glimpses of the flag hidden away? http://2018shell2.picoctf.com:60945 (link)
hints: What part of the website could tell you where the creator doesn't want you to look?
data.author: zaratec

data.name: No Login
data.description: Looks like someone started making a website but never got around to making a login, but I heard there was a flag if you were the admin. http://2018shell2.picoctf.com:52920 (link)
hints: What is it actually looking for in the cookie?
data.author: bobson

data.name: Secret Agent
data.description: Here's a little website that hasn't fully been finished. But I heard google gets all your info anyway. http://2018shell2.picoctf.com:53383 (link)
hints: How can your browser pretend to be something else?
data.author: bobson

data.name: Truly an Artist
data.description: Can you help us find the flag in this Meta-Material? You can also find the file in /problems/truly-an-artist_0_4f3e3848bbbfc5cfcfa404bd18b8ac96.
hints: Try looking beyond the image.
Who created this?
data.author: Kevin Cooper

data.name: assembly-1
data.description: What does asm1(0x255) return? Submit the flag as a hexadecimal value (starting with '0x'). NOTE: Your submission for this question will NOT be in the normal flag format. Source located in the directory at /problems/assembly-1_1_3d18f926da00c5acd1dbe672938d342d.
hints: assembly conditions
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: be-quick-or-be-dead-1
data.description: You find this when searching for some music, which leads you to be-quick-or-be-dead-1. Can you run it fast enough? You can also find the executable in /problems/be-quick-or-be-dead-1_1_d0d1dc1d01c7fd569eac77763d813c6f.
hints: What will the key finally be?
data.author: Jay Bosamiya

data.name: blaise's cipher
data.description: My buddy Blaise told me he learned about this cool cipher invented by a guy also named Blaise! Can you figure out what it says? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 59396.
hints: There are tools that make this easy.
This cipher was NOT invented by Pascal
data.author: Alex Fulton

data.name: buffer overflow 1
data.description: Okay now you're cooking! This time can you overflow the buffer and return to the flag function in this program? You can find it in /problems/buffer-overflow-1_1_8a16ff6a1b3cfb2e42c08d9090051a5d on the shell server. Source.
hints: This time you're actually going to have to control that return address!
Make sure you consider Big Endian vs Little Endian.
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: hertz 2
data.author: soup
data.description: This flag has been encrypted with some kind of cipher, can you decrypt it? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 18990.
hints: These kinds of problems are solved with a frequency that merits some analysis.

data.name: leak-me
data.description: Can you authenticate to this service and get the flag? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 38315. Source.
hints: Are all the system calls being used safely?
Some people can have reallllllly long names you know..
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: now you don't
data.description: We heard that there is something hidden in this picture. Can you find it?
hints: There is an old saying: if you want to hide the treasure, put it in plain sight. Then no one will see it.
Is it really all one shade of red?
data.author: Julio de la Cruz Natera

data.name: quackme
data.description: Can you deal with the Duck Web? Get us the flag from this program. You can also find the program in /problems/quackme_1_374d85dc071ada50a08b36597288bcfd.
hints: Objdump or something similar is probably a good place to start.
data.author: Michael Frohlich

data.name: shellcode
data.description: This program executes any input you give it. Can you get a shell? You can find the program in /problems/shellcode_3_09e0c5074980877d900d65c545d1e127 on the shell server. Source.
hints: Maybe try writing some shellcode?
You also might be able to find some good shellcode online.
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: what base is this?
data.description: To be successful on your mission, you must be able read data represented in different ways, such as hexadecimal or binary. Can you get the flag from this program to prove you are ready? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 15853.
hints: I hear python is a good means (among many) to convert things.
It might help to have multiple windows open
data.author: Alex Fulton
Jay Bosamiya
data.name: you can't see me
data.description: '...reading transmission... Y.O.U. .C.A.N.'.T. .S.E.E. .M.E.  ...transmission ended...' Maybe something lies in /problems/you-can-t-see-me_4_8bd1412e56df49a3c3757ebeb7ead77f.
hints: What command can see/read files?
What's in the manual page of ls?

data.name: Buttons
data.description: There is a website running at http://2018shell2.picoctf.com:7949 (link). Try to see if you can push their buttons.
hints: What's different about the two buttons?
data.author: Chris Hensler

data.description: We salvaged a ruined Ext SuperMagic II-class mech recently and pulled the filesystem out of the black box. It looks a bit corrupted, but maybe there's something interesting in there. You can also find it in /problems/ext-super-magic_1_c544657e659accef770d3f2bc8384a8c on the shell server.
data.author: jedavis
data.name: Ext Super Magic
hints: Are there any tools for diagnosing corrupted filesystems? What do they say if you run them on this one?
How does a linux machine know what type of file a file is?
You might find this doc helpful.
Be careful with endianness when making edits.
Once you've fixed the corruption, you can use /sbin/debugfs to pull the flag file out.

data.name: Lying Out
data.description: Some odd traffic has been detected on the network, can you identify it? More info here. Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 39410 to help us answer some questions.
data.author: Carson Sestili
speeeday
data.name: Safe RSA
data.description: Now that you know about RSA can you help us decrypt this ciphertext? We don't have the decryption key but something about those values looks funky..
hints: RSA tutorial
Hmmm that e value looks kinda small right?
These are some really big numbers.. Make sure you're using functions that don't lose any precision!

data.name: The Vault
data.description: There is a website running at http://2018shell2.picoctf.com:22430 (link). Try to see if you can login!
data.author: Chris Hensler

data.name: What's My Name?
data.description: Say my name, say my name.
hints: If you visited a website at an IP address, how does it know the name of the domain?
data.author: zaratec

data.name: absolutely relative
data.description: In a filesystem, everything is relative ¯\_(ツ)_/¯. Can you find a way to get a flag from this program? You can find it in /problems/absolutely-relative_3_c1a43555f1585c98aab8d5d2c7f0f9cc on the shell server. Source.
hints: Do you have to run the program in the same directory? (⊙.☉)7
Ever used a text editor? Check out the program 'nano'
data.author: Sam Dlinn

data.name: assembly-2
data.description: What does asm2(0x6,0x28) return? Submit the flag as a hexadecimal value (starting with '0x'). NOTE: Your submission for this question will NOT be in the normal flag format. Source located in the directory at /problems/assembly-2_0_24775b87ffbbe8e643da10e71018f275.
hints: assembly conditions
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: buffer overflow 2
data.description: Alright, this time you'll need to control some arguments. Can you get the flag from this program? You can find it in /problems/buffer-overflow-2_1_63b4b691601811c553a7c19e367737b9 on the shell server. Source.
hints: Try using gdb to print out the stack once you write to it!
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: caesar cipher 2
data.description: Can you help us decrypt this message? We believe it is a form of a caesar cipher. You can find the ciphertext in /problems/caesar-cipher-2_3_4a1aa2a4d0f79a1f8e9a29319250740a on the shell server.
hints: You'll have figure out the correct alphabet that was used to encrypt the ciphertext from the ascii character set
<a href="https://www.asciitable.com/">ASCII<a> Table
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: got-2-learn-libc
data.description: This program gives you the address of some system calls. Can you get a shell? You can find the program in /problems/got-2-learn-libc_3_6e9881e9ff61c814aafaf92921e88e33 on the shell server. Source.
hints: try returning to systems calls to leak information
don't forget you can always return back to main()
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: rsa-madlibs
data.description: We ran into some weird puzzles we think may mean something, can you help me solve one? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 36859
hints: RSA info
data.author: wparks

data.name: be-quick-or-be-dead-2
data.description: As you enjoy this music even more, another executable be-quick-or-be-dead-2 shows up. Can you run this fast enough too? You can also find the executable in /problems/be-quick-or-be-dead-2_3_bc41c1e2cd88c0e9d8a8d0cb851f91e9.
hints: Can you call stuff without executing the entire program?
What will the key finally be?
data.author: Jay Bosamiya

data.name: in out error
data.description: Can you utlize stdin, stdout, and stderr to get the flag from this program? You can also find it in /problems/in-out-error_1_24ebc7186086f0f9a710de008628c561 on the shell server
hints: Maybe you can split the stdout and stderr output?
data.author: Sam Dlinn

data.name: Artisinal Handcrafted HTTP 3
data.description: We found a hidden flag server hiding behind a proxy, but the proxy has some... _interesting_ ideas of what qualifies someone to make HTTP requests. Looks like you'll have to do this one by hand. Try connecting via nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 36186, and use the proxy to send HTTP requests to `flag.local`. We've also recovered a username and a password for you to use on the login page: `realbusinessuser`/`potoooooooo`.
hints: _Be the browser._  When you navigate to a page, how does your browser send HTTP requests?  How does this change when you submit a form?
data.author: Matthew Savage
invisibility
data.name: SpyFi
data.description: James Brahm, James Bond's less-franchised cousin, has left his secure communication with HQ running, but we couldn't find a way to steal his agent identification code. Can you? Conect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 37131. Source.
hints: What mode is being used?

data.name: echooo
data.description: This program prints any input you give it. Can you leak the flag? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 23397. Source.
hints: If only the program used puts...
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: learn gdb
data.description: Using a debugging tool will be extremely useful on your missions. Can you run this program in gdb and find the flag? You can find the file in /problems/learn-gdb_2_32e08c18932eb88649e9b97f3020b9f5 on the shell server.
hints: Try setting breakpoints in gdb
Try and find a point in the program after the flag has been read into memory to break on
Where is the flag being written in memory?
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: Flaskcards
data.description: We found this fishy website for flashcards that we think may be sending secrets. Could you take a look?
hints: Are there any common vulnerabilities with the backend of the website?
Is there anywhere that filtering doesn't get applied?
The database gets reverted every 2 hours so your session might end unexpectedly. Just make another user
data.author: Austin McWhirter

data.name: Super Safe RSA
data.description: Dr. Xernon made the mistake of rolling his own crypto.. Can you find the bug and decrypt the message? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 6262.
hints: Just try the first thing that comes to mind.
data.author: invisibility

data.name: authenticate
data.description: Can you authenticate to this service and get the flag? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 26336. Source.
hints: What happens if you say something OTHER than yes or no?
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: be-quick-or-be-dead-3
data.description: As the song draws closer to the end, another executable be-quick-or-be-dead-3 suddenly pops up. This one requires even faster machines. Can you run it fast enough too? You can also find the executable in /problems/be-quick-or-be-dead-3_0_fa64b8365f5d2ac445b925be0960b943.
hints: How do you speed up a very repetitive computation?
data.author: Jay Bosamiya
jedavis
data.description: This program was about to print the flag when it died. Maybe the flag is still in this core file that it dumped? Also available at /problems/core_2_6f573d741fe8c5c6518e4a29f04a1e19 on the shell server.
hints: What is a core file?
You may find this reference helpful.
Try to figure out where the flag was read into memory using the disassembly and strace.
You should study the format options on the cheat sheet and use the examine (x) or print (p) commands. disas may also be useful.
data.name: core
got-shell?
data.description: Can you authenticate to this service and get the flag? Connect to it with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 46464. Source
hints: Ever heard of the Global Offset Table?
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: quackme up
data.description: The duck puns continue. Can you crack, I mean quack this program as well? You can find the program in /problems/quackme-up_4_5cc9019c8499d6d124cd8e8109a0f95b on the shell server.
data.author: Michael Frohlich

data.name: rop chain
data.description: Can you exploit the following program and get the flag? You can findi the program in /problems/rop-chain_0_6cdbecac1c3aa2316425c7d44e6ddf9d on the shell server? Source.
hints: Try and call the functions in the correct order!
Remember, you can always call main() again!
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: roulette
data.description: This Online Roulette Service is in Beta. Can you find a way to win $1,000,000,000 and get the flag? Source. Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 48312
hints: There are 2 bugs!
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: Malware Shops
data.description: There has been some malware detected, can you help with the analysis? More info here. Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 57920.
data.author: Carson Sestili

data.name: Radix's Terminal
data.description: Can you find the password to Radix's login? You can also find the executable in /problems/radix-s-terminal_4_ae97ed559436608827a568341938c2a4?
hints: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Base64
data.author: Sanjay C

data.description: What does asm3(0xf238999b,0xda0f9ac5,0xcc85310c) return? Submit the flag as a hexadecimal value (starting with '0x'). NOTE: Your submission for this question will NOT be in the normal flag format. Source located in the directory at /problems/assembly-3_2_504fe35f4236db611941d162e2abc6b9.

Jay Bosamiya
data.name: eleCTRic
data.description: You came across a custom server that Dr Xernon's company eleCTRic Ltd uses. It seems to be storing some encrypted files. Can you get us the flag? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 36150. Source.
hints: I have repeated myself many many many times- do not repeat yourself.
Do I need to say it in different words? You mustn't repeat thyself.

data.name: fancy-alive-monitoring
data.description: One of my school mate developed an alive monitoring tool. Can you get a flag from http://2018shell2.picoctf.com:56517 (link)?
hints: This application uses the validation check both on the client side and on the server side, but the server check seems to be inappropriate.
You should be able to listen through the shell on the server.
data.author: rintaro

data.name: keygen-me-1
data.description: Can you generate a valid product key for the validation program in /problems/keygen-me-1_3_a2370158b7b72b3863212502340f2c32
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: store
data.description: We started a little store, can you buy the flag? Source. Connect with 2018shell2.picoctf.com 5795.
hints: Two's compliment can do some weird things when numbers get really big!
data.author: Danny
invisibility
data.name: Super Safe RSA 2
data.description: Wow, he made the exponent really large so the encryption MUST be safe, right?! Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 47295.
hints: What is the usual value for e?

data.name: Magic Padding Oracle
data.description: Can you help us retreive the flag from this crypto service? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 45008. We were able to recover some Source Code.
hints: Paddding Oracle Attack
data.author: Martin Carlisle/Alex Fulton

data.name: buffer overflow 3
data.description: It looks like Dr. Xernon added a stack canary to this program to protect against buffer overflows. Do you think you can bypass the protection and get the flag? You can find it in /problems/buffer-overflow-3_2_810c6904c19a0e8b0da0f59eade5b0ce. Source.
hints: Maybe there's a smart way to brute-force the canary?
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: Secure Logon
data.description: Uh oh, the login page is more secure... I think. http://2018shell2.picoctf.com:56265 (link). Source.
hints: There are versions of AES that really aren't secure.
data.author: bobson

data.name: echo back
data.description: This program we found seems to have a vulnerability. Can you get a shell and retreive the flag? Connect to it with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 26532.
hints: hmm, printf seems to be dangerous...
You may need to modify more than one address at once.
Ever heard of the Global Offset Table?
data.author: rintaro

data.name: script me
data.description: Can you understand the language and answer the questions to retrieve the flag? Connect to the service with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 22973
hints: Maybe try writing a python script?
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: LoadSomeBits
data.description: Can you find the flag encoded inside this image? You can also find the file in /problems/loadsomebits_1_5ccf71e5726692c713405bb17da5cb37 on the shell server.
hints: Look through the Least Significant Bits for the image
If you interpret a binary sequence (seq) as ascii and then try interpreting the same binary sequence from an offset of 1 (seq[1:]) as ascii do you get something similar or completely different?
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: are you root?
data.description: Can you get root access through this service and get the flag? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 29508. Source.
hints: If only the program used calloc to zero out the memory..
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: assembly-4
data.description: Can you find the flag using the following assembly source? WARNING: It is VERY long...
hints: Hmm.. There must be an easier way than reversing the whole thing right?
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: gps
data.description: You got really lost in the wilderness, with nothing but your trusty gps. Can you find your way back to a shell and get the flag? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 21755. (Source).
hints: Can you make your shellcode randomization-resistant?
data.author: Strikeskids

data.name: Flaskcards Skeleton Key
data.description: Nice! You found out they were sending the Secret_key: 385c16dd09098b011d0086f9e218a0a2. Now, can you find a way to log in as admin? http://2018shell2.picoctf.com:48263 (link).
hints: What can you do with a flask Secret_Key?
The database still reverts every 2 hours
data.author: Austin McWhirter

data.name: Help Me Reset 2
data.description: There is a website running at http://2018shell2.picoctf.com:53126 (link). We need to get into any user for a flag!
hints: Try looking past the typical vulnerabilities.  Think about possible programming mistakes.
data.author: Kevin Cooper

data.name: Super Safe RSA 3
data.author: invisibility
data.description: The more primes, the safer.. right.?.? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 11423.
hints: How would you find d if there are more than 2 prime factors of n?

data.name: special-pw
data.description: Can you figure out the right argument to this program to login? We couldn't manage to get a copy of the binary but we did manage to dump some machine code and memory from the running process.
hints: Hmmm maybe if we do the reverse of each operation we can get the password?
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: A Simple Question
data.description: There is a website running at http://2018shell2.picoctf.com:28120 (link). Try to see if you can answer its question.
data.author: Chris Hensler

data.name: can-you-gets-me
data.description: Can you exploit the following program to get a flag? You may need to think return-oriented if you want to program your way to the flag. You can find the program in /problems/can-you-gets-me_4_f269dbca3097204b5d4a0064467b0a8c on the shell server. Source.
hints: This is a classic gets ROP
data.author: Sanjay C
invisibility
data.name: James Brahm Returns
data.description: Dr. Xernon has finally approved an update to James Brahm's spy terminal. (Someone finally told them that ECB isn't secure.) Fortunately, CBC mode is safe! Right? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 37440. Source.
hints: What killed SSL3?

data.name: freecalc
data.description: Things are heating up! Can you help us exploit this program and get us the flag? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 59874 Source. libc.so.6
hints: You probably need to leak both a heap address and a libc address
Define a function as: <function_name> <number_of_commands> <command_1> <command_2> ...
Make sure you are run/debug with the provided libc on the shell server
data.author: sdamashek

data.name: keygen-me-2
data.description: The software has been updated. Can you find us a new product key for the program in /problems/keygen-me-2_0_ac2a45bc27456d666f2bbb6921829203
hints: z3
data.author: Sanjay C

data.name: LambDash 3
data.description: C? Who uses that anymore. If we really want to be secure, we should all start learning lambda calculus. http://2018shell2.picoctf.com:4927 (link)
hints: This compiler is 99.9% bug free! I'm sure the other 0.1% won't amount to anything...
data.author: Zachary Wade

data.name: circuit123
data.description: Can you crack the key to decrypt map2 for us? The key to map1 is 11443513758266689915.
hints: Have you heard of z3?
data.author: Thiner

data.name: sword
data.description: Can you spawn a shell and get the flag? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 44116. Source. libc.so.6
hints: ever heard of use after free?
Make sure you are run/debug with the provided libc on the shell server
data.author: 1ce0ear
tjbecker
data.name: Contacts
data.description: This program for storing your contacts is currently in beta. Can you hijack control and get a shell? Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 56667. Source. libc.so.6
hints: If only the author used calloc() instead...
fastbin fastbin fastbin
Make sure you are run/debug with the provided libc on the shell server

data.name: Cake
data.description: Now that you're a professional heap baker, can you pwn this for us? It should be a piece of cake. Connect with nc 2018shell2.picoctf.com 39932. libc.so.6
hints: If at first you don't succeed, try, try, try again.
Make sure you are run/debug with the provided libc on the shell server
data.author: Strikeskids

data.name: Dog or Frog
data.description: Dressing up dogs are kinda the new thing, see if you can get this lovely girl ready for her costume party. Dog Or Frog
hints: This really is a ML problem, read the hints in the problem for more details..
data.author: wpakrs/emontano web/afulton port
